Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Developing Teaching Assistant Expertise with a Sensor-Based Learning System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
While a college degree is essential for many jobs or career paths, many college students receive a less than ideal educational experience. For years, research has shown that moving away from large lectures and increasing student engagement and participation significantly improves learning. However, most colleges still rely on lectures where students passively receive information from professors, and instructors continue to teach in the ways in which they themselves were taught. This project addresses this large-scale societal problem of understanding and supporting instructor learning by investigating how to support teaching assistants (TAs) to acquire student-centered teaching skills before they transition to faculty. This exploratory research project will investigate the development of an advanced learning technology system that integrates multimodal sensory data to deliver near real-time data on teaching practices. The combined reflection and training system will provide rapid and frequent feedback and instruction on good strategies to support student-centered teaching beliefs and behaviors. In turn, the project will advance understanding of how instructors engage with personal informatics to impact beliefs and behaviors related to teacher professional development.

In this exploratory project, a learning system for TAs will be developed, consisting of an interconnected set of modules that support them in acquiring student-centered teaching practices through the provision of a dashboard with near-real-time multimodal classroom data. The system draws upon technical and socio-technical advances in sensing arrays, computer vision, intelligent environments, and personal informatics, together with frameworks of professional development in higher education. The project advances computing by expanding the capabilities of state of the art multimodal sensing approaches to achieve non-invasive sensing at classroom-scale. Through a series of design-based research studies with TAs who are teaching STEM college courses, the project investigates: a) the ways in which this system can present personal data to foster productive self-doubt, b) how engagement with personal data leads to a motivation to change, and c) how data-driven instruction can foster self-efficacy in teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant investigated the use of smart classroom technology to improve the quality of college teaching by sensing teacher and student actions, providing feedback to teachers on their teaching actions, and offering instructional materials on best practices in teaching. We made use of several smart classrooms that use a vision system to collect data on college classes. 

Over the course of this project, we developed a focus on immediacy, the feeling a teacher can produce in a student that they are noticed and attended to, as it relates to non-verbal teacher behaviors that co-vary with immediacy. These include looking at students (as opposed to a laptop or a whiteboard), moving so that a podium does not create a barrier between students and teachers, moving into the classroom to close the distance between teacher and students, and developing an open and welcoming posture.

The main activities this research supported include:

  • Data collection of teacher and student behaviors from 25, semester long college STEM classes.

  • Development of a web-based dashboard that displays feedback to instructors on their immediacy measures. It also offers instructional material for college instructors, who unlike k-12 teachers, do not participate in professional development and often do not know how their teaching actions impact student learning.

  • Exploratory interviews with instructors investigating how they would like to engage with a smart classroom to improve their teaching

  • Assessment interviews with college instructors who used our dashboard to explore and reflect on their teaching, and where instructors set goals and made plans to change their teaching practices.

In our exploratory interviews, we discovered clear motivators and barriers for engaging high school teachers in Personal Informatics of their teaching. Specifically, they:

  • Want to see how they give their attention to students

  • Want to see this as a replacement for some required Professional Development that they do not feel is relevant or challenging

  • Worry administrators will misuse this data to punish teachers

At the college level, we found a clear connection between belief and interpretation of data. This indicates that systems must work on belief change first if they want to meaningfully drive behavior change: teachers should be guided towards student-centered views of learning if we want them to adopt student-centered behaviors. We found that university instructors had not had prior training on immediacy skills, yet had a strong interest in collecting data on their non-verbal behaviors as a way of improving their teaching and operationalizing best practices in teaching. Instructors showed interest in knowing more about how they moved within the classroom and particularly in knowing more about their eye gaze. We wanted to know if they looked at their students and if they spread their attention equally across all students. Immediacy and non-verbal teaching behaviors related to immediacy appeared to be a rich space where instructors felt they could set goals for behaviors they wanted to change and where they could develop strategies that worked for their classroom and for their preferred style of teaching.

After working with the dashboard, instructors reported that they learned a significant amount from the professional development opportunities provided. They reported the perception that they learned more from seeing their own data in the dashboard module than seeing the PD module.

The assessment of the dashboards showed it was effective at getting instructors to set explicit behavior change goals. Almost every instructor talked about increasing eye contact. However, they also frequently blamed the classroom design, which often placed a podium as a barrier between them and students and positioned them within the room far from the students. Interviews showed that instructors faced challenges in changing their behaviors; however, they scored moderately high on proxy measures for behavior change. Interestingly, instructors who receive motivational feedback from our dashboard through social comparison to other instructors scored higher in intent to change behavior as well as proxies for behavior change compared to instructors who received motivational feedback through verbal persuasion. We feel that these findings have implications for designing technologies that best support and motivate instructor’s goal setting and behavior change efforts. They have supported our iteration of the data-driven teacher professional development framework, which is in the process of publication. 

In educational outcomes, this grant provided professional development to dozens of university instructors. It also funded one successful PhD thesis with a second expected shortly, in addition to providing research experiences to dozens of undergraduate and master’s students across many disciplines.
